Key Arguments: The legislation imposes a form of civil conscription on medical practitioners by compelling them to write prescriptions on Commonwealth forms.
Section 7A of the Act is invalid as it violates the constitutional prohibition against civil conscription.
The Act goes beyond the powers conferred by the constitutional amendment, particularly in its application to medical practitioners.
The Act interferes with the practice of medicine by imposing compulsory duties on doctors, which is not authorized by the Constitution.
Notable Quotes: The Act does not in any way assume Commonwealth control of State institutions such as hospitals &c. It only offers to them an opportunity of coming into the Commonwealth scheme if they think fit.
Section 7A imposes a form of civil conscription.
The prohibition of 'any form' of civil conscription prevents any compulsory service being required under a Federal law for the provision of pharmaceutical benefits.
